GOVERNMENT OF INDIA 
BUREAU OF CIVIL AVIATION SECURITY 
(MINISTRY OF CIVIL AVIATION) 
A’ WING JANPATH BHAWAN 
JANPATH, NEW DELHI 
Dated: 31/12/2009 
 
 
AVSEC CIRCULAR NO. 24/2009 
 
 
Subject:- New Technique of smuggling explosive material. 
 
Recently, a passenger allegedly smuggled explosive materials into an US 
air carrier and attempted to destroy it.  
 
 
The passenger set off the device, that was attached to his body, resulting 
in a fire and fire cracker like popping explosions. Preliminary analysis revealed 
that the device contained about 76 grams of finely powdered PETN ( 
Pentaerythritol), a high explosive. Authorities also recovered, what appeared to 
be remnants of a syringe from the vicinity of the said passenger’s seat. The 
underwear worn by him was modified to provide storage of the main charge 
which was anatomically congruent, possibly to avoid detection during screening. 
The underwear and the jeans worn by him sustained thermal damage on the 
inside with small spots of melted plastic on the outer surface. The syringe which 
was used as an initiator revealed presence of ethylene glycol, a component of 
various commercially manufactured items, including coolants and anti-freezes. 
The passenger went to the bathroom for approximately 20 minutes  on board the 
aircraft. On return to his seat, he stated that he had an upset stomach and pulled 
a blanket over himself. This was followed by popping noises similar to fire 
crackers, an odour and fire on the passenger’s pant and wall of the airplane. 
  
 
In view of the above, all concerned may be sensitized to prevent any such 
attempt of acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation operation.  
 
 
This has the approval of Commissioner of Security (CA) 
 
 
 
( M.Malaviya, IPS) 
Addl. Commissioner of Security (CA)
